titleStmt.title: Description of Free Library of Philadelphia, Widener 1: La voie de Povreté ou de Richesse (The Way of Poverty or of Wealth)

notesStmt.note: Last sixteen lines of text lacking
Dated to c. 1430 by E. König (p. 193); formerly dated to c. 1430-1440 (cf. Leaves of Gold, p. 202)

Descriptions of the images are partially based on Le Livre du Chastel de Labour, par Jean Bruyant: A Description of an Illuminated Manuscript of the Fifteenth Century, Belonging to George C. Thomas, Philadelphia, with a Short Account and Synopsis of the Poem (Philadelphia: 1909)
Leopold Delisle, Catalogue des manuscrits des fonds Libri et Barrois (Paris: H. Champion, 1888), p. 284.

Le Livre du Chastel de Labour, par jean Bruyant: A Description of an Illuminated Manuscript of the Fifteenth Century, Belonging to George C. Thomas, Philadelphia, with a Short Account and Synopsis of the Poem, translation by Francois William Bourdillon (Philadelphia: 1909).
Arthur Långfors, "Jacques Bruyant et son poème La Voie de Povreté ou de Richesse," Romania 45 (1918-1919), pp. 49-83.
De Ricci, Seymour, with the assistance of W. J. Wilson, Census of Medieval and Renaissance Manuscripts in the United States and Canada, vol. 2 (New York,: H. W. Wilson, 1935-40), p. 2115, no. 1

Edwin Wolf 2nd ed., Legacies of Genius: A Celebration of Philadelphia Libraries, a Selection of Books, Manuscripts, and Works of Art (Philadelphia: Philadelphia Area Consortium of Special Collections Libraries, 1988), p. 36, no. 3.
Wolf, Edwin, with John F. Fleming, Rosenbach: A Biography (Cleveland and New York: World Publishing, 1960), p. 67.
Philadelphia Museum of Art, Leaves of Gold: Manuscript Illumination from Philadelphia Collections, edited by James R. Tanis (Philadelphia: Philadelphia Museum of Art, 2001), pp. 203-205, no. 70.
König, Eberhard and Gabriele Bartz, Das Buch vom erfüllten Leben: Jacques Bruyant, Le Livre du Chastel de Labour, Widener 1, The Free Library of Philadelphia (Lucerne: Faksimile Verlag Luzern, 2005).

Scott, Anne M., "Le Chastel de Labour, La Voie de Povreté ou de Richesse and a Luxury Book, Widener 1, Free Library of Philadelphia," in Anne M. Scott, ed., Experiences of Poverty in Late Medieval and Early Modern England and France (Farnham: Ashgate, 2012), pp. 253-277.
Epurescu-Pascovici, Ionut, "Le Chemin de Povreté et de Richesse and the Late Medieval Social Imaginary," French Historical Studies, 36.1 (2013), pp. 19-50.
Cropp, Glynnis M., La voie de povreté et de richesse (Cambridge: Modern Humanities Research Association, 2016).

msContents.summary: This fifteenth-century French manuscript, made in Paris, contains the text of the allegorical poem, La Voie de Povreté ou de Richesse (The Way of Poverty or of Wealth), originally written circa 1342 by the French poet Jacques Bruyant. The allegorical dream vision follows the progress of a newlywed man through his dream, accompanied by the figure of Raison, from whom he learns the virtues of undertaking hard work, while laboring as a craftsman in the Chastel de Labor. The final sixteen lines of the poem are missing from this manuscript. This copy is lavishly illuminated, featuring forty-five miniatures attributed to the Fastolf Master during his tenure in the workshop of the Bedford Master. Each of the miniatures introduces one of the poem's forty-six chapters, along with rubricated captions; the images are framed with full foliate borders, while partial foliate borders frame certain text blocks. Within the borders are marginal drawings, such as depictions of birds, the poem's "castle of labor," and the frequently-replicated Beaville family coat of arms, in addition to crests and banderoles with their motto "Nulle que vous."

msItem.title: La voie de Povreté ou de Richesse (The Way of Poverty or of Wealth)
msItem.author: Bruyant, Jean, active 14th century

msItem.title: La Voie de Povreté ou de Richesse
msItem.incipit: On dit souvent a reprochier / un proverbe que iay moult …
msItem.explicit: … Que veoiz me puisse ou demaine [fol. 73v]

supportDesc.foliation: Modern foliation in pencil in upper right hand corners

layoutDesc.layout: Written area: 113 x 72 mm;1 column of 26 lines, ruled in red ink; 46 half-page miniatures with full foliate borders of the rinceaux type, 1 historiated roundel in margin (fol. 1r) and marginal scenes in border of fol. 61v; decorated 2-line initials throughout; heraldic devices and the motto "Nulle que vous" appearing in some margins

decoDesc.decoNote: Forty-five large miniatures with rubricated captions; full foliate borders with marginal decoration, including the coat of arms of the Beauville family, and illuminated initials throughout
Inside front coverEx Libris, Joseph Widener
1rLarge miniature, Want, Necessity, Suffering, and Hunger visit Newlywed
1rAuthor portrait in rondel, Jacques Bruyant reading
2rSmall miniature, Besoing, Necessité, Souffraite, et Dissette invade the chamber of the newlyweds
3rLarge miniature, Pensée and Soussy assault the newlyweds
5rMarginal drawing, Crest with motto, Nulle que vous
5vMarginal drawing, Gold box with banderoles featuring motto, Nulle que vous
7rMiniature, Raison enters the chamber of the newlyweds, chases away Désespérance
8rLarge miniature, Raison admonishes and teaches the new messenger
10rMarginal drawing, weasel carrying banderole with motto "Nulle que vous"
11rLarge miniature, Raison speaks to the new messenger of the sin of Envy
11rMarginal drawing, gold box with banderoles featuring motto, Nulle que vous
12rLarge miniature, Raison speaks to the messenger of the sin of Ire
14rLarge miniature, Raison speaks about the sin of Paresce and the virtue of Diligence
15vLarge miniature, Raison declares the sin of covetousnenss and usury
15vMarginal drawing, banderole with motto "Nulle que vous"
17rLarge miniature, Raison declares the sin of glutony and its contrary virtues, such as abstinence and sobriété
17rMarginal drawing, two banderoles with motto "Nulle que vous"
18vLarge miniature, Raison speaks of the sin of luxuriance and of the virtue of chastity
21rLarge miniature, Raison councils the newlyweds that they should only lie together for the sake of procreation
22rLarge miniature, Raison offers weights and a scale to the newlywed
23vLarge miniature, Raison escorts the newlywed to the Chastel de Richesse
23vMarginal drawing, gold box with banderoles featuring motto "Nulle que vous"
26rLarge miniature, Raison with the newlywed and the Three Fates, each hold banderoles feaurting their names
26rMarginal drawing, crest with gold box featuring banderoles with motto "Nulle que vous"
28rLarge miniature, Raison shows Newlywed the path to the House of Poverty
29rLarge miniature, Raison shows the newlywed the two diverging paths of Convoitise and Souffisance
32rLarge miniature, Raison recommends the path of Souffisance to the newlywed
33vLarge miniature, Raison enjoins the newlywed to serve his master faithfully
33vMarginal drawing, bird with banderoles featuring motto "Nulle que vous"
34vLarge miniature, Raison and the newlywed standing with a servent dressed in black
36rLarge miniature, Raison leaves and Entendement visits the newlywed
37rLarge miniature, The newlywed with the Clerk, the Advocate, and the Varlet in the bedroom
38rLarge miniature, The newlywed with the Clerk, the Advocate, and the Varlet in the garden
38rMarginal drawing, banderole with motto "Nulle que vous"
39vLarge miniature, The newlywed with the Clerk, the Advocate, and the Varlet in the garden
41vLarge miniature, The Clerk, the Advocate, and the Varlet leave the newlywed alone in the garden
41vMarginal drawing, crest with gold box featuring banderoles with motto "Nulle que vous"
43vLarge miniature, Entendement scolds the newlywed in the garden, cherub with banderole labled "Intelligencia" above Entendement's head
45rLarge miniature, Entendement teaches the newlywed to believe in and obey the commandments of Raison, cherub with banderole labeled "Intelligencia" above his head
47rLarge miniature, newlywed pledging his fealty to Raison
49rLarge miniature, The newlywed is shown the rewards of reason and the punishments of fraud
49rMarginal drawing, bird with banderole featuring motto "Nulle que vous"
53vLarge miniature, Raison bends to kiss the newlywed outside in the garden
53vMarginal drawing, bird with banderole featuring motto "Nulle que vous"
54vLarge miniature, A man, Bon Cuer, and woman, Bonne Voulente, lead the child, Talent, to the newlywed whose wife is sleeping
54vMarginal drawing, two banderoles with motto "Nulle que vous"
55vLarge miniature, Talent, Bonne Voulente, and Bon Cuer sit beside the newlywed and his wife in bed
55vMarginal drawing, gold box with banderoles featuring motto "Nulle que vous"
57vLarge miniature, Talent, Bonne Voulente, and Bon Cuer lead the newlywed to the Richesse's castle
58vLarge miniature, The newlywed at the gate of the castle with Talent, Bon Cuer, Bonne Voulente, and the porter, Soing
58vMarginal drawing, gold box with banderoles featuring motto "Nulle que vous"
60rLarge miniature, The newlywed at the gate of the castle with Talent, Bon Cuer, Bonne Voulente, and the porter, Soing, who takes the hands of the newlywed
60rMarginal drawing, crest with gold box with banderoles featuring motto "Nulle que vous"
61vLarge miniature, The newlywed takes his place as a worker in the castle with other workers
61vMarginal drawing, figures performing the primary labors of the four seasons: sowing, reaping, woodcutting, and grape gathering.
63vLarge miniature, Paine, Soing and Cure look on while the newlywed labors as a blacksmith in the castle
64vLarge miniature, Paine encourages the newlywed as he works
66rLarge miniature, Laborers working and eating in the fields of the Chastel de Labor
67rLarge miniature, The newlywed sits at a table with Bon Cuer, Bonne Voulente, and Talent standing behind him, while Travail walks in to the room
68vLarge miniature, The newlywed exits the castle as Cure and Soing bid him farewell; Cure holds a banderole with the words ".O. r[e]viens matin"
68vMarginal drawing, gold box with banderoles featuring motto "Nulle que vous"
70vLarge miniature, The newlywed tells his wife of his dream as she sets the table for supper in their home
72vLarge miniature, The newlywed, holding a tinder box, in the bedroom with his wife who responds to his narrative
72vMarginal drawing, gold box with banderoles featuring motto "Nulle que vous"

binding.p: Late 19th or early 20th century, French, red velvet cover boards with silver corner pieces, gilt edges

history.provenance: Made for the Beuville family, seigneurs de la Seraulté, Normandy (15th century); "Jean Berger", (16th century?); Alisié (bookseller), Paris, 1891; Joseph Baer, Frankfurt, May 1900; George Clifford Thomas, Philadelphia; Ada E. Moorhead Thomas, Philadelphia; P. A. B. Widener, Philadelphia (through A. S. W. Rosenbach, October 19, 1910; Joseph E. Widener, 1915; given to FLP in 1944 by gift of his children, Josephine Widener Wichfeld and Peter A. B. Widener, in memory of their father; Coats of arms of Beuville family, seigneurs de la Seraulté, Normandy (de geueles semé de mouchetures d'hermine d'argent à fleur de lys brochant du même), and their motto "nulle que vous" in some borders; fol. 1r: Name "Jean Berger" inscribed in lower margin; Ex libris of Joseph Widener; "Inv. no. 1074" inscribed on detached leaf inserted at end of book
